episodeTitle: Hawk-Eye Mihawk! The Great Swordsman Zoro Falls At Sea!
episodeTitleJapanese: 鷹の目のミホーク！剣豪ゾロ海に散る
episodeTitleRomanized: Taka no me no Mihōku! Kengō Zoro umi ni chiru
description: Zoro challenges the legendary Dracule Mihawk, one of the Seven Warlords of the Sea, to a duel. Despite fighting with all his strength, Zoro is completely overwhelmed and severely wounded. In defeat, Zoro makes a solemn vow to Luffy and himself that he will never lose again until he becomes the world's greatest swordsman.

events.title: Johnny and Yosaku Explain Nami's Departure
events.description: Johnny and Yosaku reveal to Luffy and the others how Nami stole the Going Merry, pushing them both overboard and declaring she had 'business' to take care of.
events.significance: Sets up the mystery of Nami's betrayal and her true motivations, which will be explored in the Arlong Park arc.

quotes.text: She said she had business to take care of!
quotes.speaker: Yosaku
quotes.context: Explaining why Nami stole the Going Merry

events.title: Dracule Mihawk Makes His Entrance
events.description: A mysterious man sailing alone on a coffin-shaped boat arrives at the Baratie. He is revealed to be Dracule 'Hawk-Eye' Mihawk, one of the Seven Warlords of the Sea and the world's greatest swordsman.
events.significance: Mihawk's debut establishes the incredible power gap between East Blue pirates and Grand Line warriors. His appearance introduces the concept of the Shichibukai (Seven Warlords) system to the series.

events.title: Seven Warlords of the Sea Explained
events.description: Johnny and Yosaku explain the power structure of the world, revealing that Mihawk is one of the Seven Warlords of the Sea (Shichibukai), government-sanctioned pirates who serve as one of the Three Great Powers alongside the Marines and the Four Emperors.
events.significance: First major explanation of the world's power structure, introducing the Shichibukai system which will play a crucial role throughout the series.

events.title: Mihawk Destroyed Krieg's Fleet
events.description: It's revealed that Mihawk single-handedly destroyed Don Krieg's entire armada of 50 ships when they entered the Grand Line, simply because he was bored and looking for entertainment.
events.significance: Demonstrates the vast difference in power between East Blue pirates and Grand Line level fighters. Shows the casual cruelty and overwhelming strength of top-tier warriors.

quotes.text: I attacked them merely to pass the time.
quotes.speaker: Mihawk
quotes.context: Explaining why he destroyed Krieg's fleet

events.title: Zoro Challenges Mihawk to a Duel
events.description: Despite knowing he's outmatched, Zoro steps forward and challenges Mihawk to a duel, declaring his dream to become the world's greatest swordsman. He cannot let the opportunity pass to test himself against the strongest.
events.significance: This moment defines Zoro's character - his willingness to face impossible odds in pursuit of his dream. Sets up one of the most iconic early fights in One Piece.

quotes.text: I have a duty to fight you. My name may be unknown now, but I will become the greatest swordsman in the world!
quotes.speaker: Zoro

events.title: The Duel Begins - Mihawk's Small Dagger
events.description: Mihawk accepts Zoro's challenge but initially fights using only a small cross-shaped pendant dagger, explaining that he doesn't need his great sword Yoru to fight someone from the weakest sea.
events.significance: Demonstrates the massive power gap between Mihawk and Zoro. Mihawk's choice to use a small knife is both an insult and a lesson about the gulf in their abilities.

quotes.text: I'm not the kind of fool who hunts rabbits with a cannon. This tiny blade is more than enough for the East Blue.
quotes.speaker: Mihawk
quotes.context: Drawing his small dagger instead of Yoru

events.title: Mihawk's Kogatana Technique
events.description: Mihawk effortlessly blocks all of Zoro's three-sword style attacks using only his small pendant knife, demonstrating his mastery of technique and observation.
events.significance: Shows that swordsmanship is about more than just strength or the number of blades - it's about skill, precision, and will.

events.title: Kuina Flashback - Zoro's Promise
events.description: As Zoro struggles in the fight, he has a flashback to his childhood friend Kuina and the promise they made - that one of them would become the world's greatest swordsman. This memory strengthens his resolve.
events.significance: Reveals the emotional core of Zoro's dream and why he can never back down from a challenge, even when facing certain defeat.

quotes.text: Let's make a promise. One of us will become the world's greatest swordsman!
quotes.speaker: Kuina

events.title: Mihawk Draws Yoru
events.description: Impressed by Zoro's determination and spirit, Mihawk decides to honor him as a swordsman by drawing his black blade Yoru, the strongest sword in the world, to finish the duel properly.
events.significance: Shows Mihawk's respect for Zoro despite the power gap. The first appearance of Yoru, which will become one of the most iconic weapons in the series.

quotes.text: You are strong. I haven't met a swordsman like you in ages. As a show of respect, I'll use this black blade to end your life.
quotes.speaker: Mihawk
quotes.context: Drawing Yoru to properly duel Zoro

events.title: Zoro's Two Swords Shatter
events.description: Mihawk's attack with Yoru destroys two of Zoro's three swords, leaving only the Wado Ichimonji intact. The two ungraded blades cannot withstand the power of Yoru, the supreme grade black blade.
events.significance: Demonstrates the importance of sword quality and the concept of black blades. Wado Ichimonji surviving shows its special nature as a Great Grade sword and Kuina's treasure.

events.title: Zoro Accepts Defeat Face-Forward
events.description: Rather than flee or turn his back, Zoro sheathes Wado Ichimonji and faces Mihawk directly, accepting the killing blow. He states that a scar on the back is a swordsman's shame.
events.significance: Defines Zoro's code as a swordsman - he would rather die than dishonor himself by running. This act of courage earns Mihawk's ultimate respect.

quotes.text: A wound on the back is a swordsman's shame!
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Refusing to run from Mihawk's final strike

events.title: Mihawk Spares Zoro's Life
events.description: Mihawk slashes Zoro across the chest but deliberately spares his life, impressed by his courage and determination. He tells Zoro to grow stronger and surpass him someday.
events.significance: This moment of mercy defines the relationship between Mihawk and Zoro. Mihawk sees potential in Zoro and wants a worthy rival in the future. It's a non-fatal 'death' event that profoundly changes Zoro.

quotes.text: It's too soon for you to die. My name is Dracule Mihawk! Discover yourself, grow strong, and return to challenge me again!
quotes.speaker: Mihawk

events.title: Zoro's Vow to Never Lose Again
events.description: After the duel, Zoro raises his sword to the sky and makes a solemn vow to Luffy that he will never lose another battle until he defeats Mihawk and becomes the world's greatest swordsman.
events.significance: One of the most iconic moments in One Piece. This vow becomes the cornerstone of Zoro's character development and his loyalty to Luffy. It shows his determination despite overwhelming defeat.

quotes.text: Luffy... can you hear me? I'm sorry for worrying you. If I fail to become the world's greatest swordsman, you'll be disappointed, right? I will never lose again! Until I defeat him and become the greatest, I will never lose again!
quotes.speaker: Zoro

events.title: Mihawk Departs
events.description: Satisfied with the duel, Mihawk decides not to pursue the Krieg Pirates any further and sails away on his coffin boat, leaving Don Krieg to begin his invasion of the Baratie.
events.significance: Allows the Baratie arc to continue with the Krieg battle. Shows that Mihawk truly was just passing time and has no real interest in the weak East Blue pirates.

events.title: Don Krieg Begins Invasion of Baratie
events.description: With Mihawk gone, Don Krieg and his remaining crew prepare to invade the Baratie restaurant, seeking to take it as their new pirate ship.
events.significance: Sets up the next phase of the Baratie arc - the battle against Don Krieg and his forces.

events.title: Luffy Orders Zoro and Usopp to Pursue Nami
events.description: Luffy orders the wounded Zoro and Usopp to go after Nami with Johnny and Yosaku while he stays behind to deal with Don Krieg himself.
events.significance: Shows Luffy's trust in his crew and his willingness to take on major threats alone. Sets up the split that leads to the Arlong Park arc.

events.title: Zeff Agrees to Nullify Luffy's Debt
events.description: Chef Zeff agrees to nullify Luffy's debt for damaging the Baratie if Luffy successfully repels Don Krieg's invasion, showing his trust in the young pirate.
events.significance: Shows the growing respect between Luffy and Zeff. Sets the stakes for the upcoming Krieg battle.

quotes.text: I attacked them merely to pass the time.
quotes.speaker: Mihawk
quotes.context: Explaining his pursuit of Krieg's fleet

quotes.text: I have a duty to fight you. My name may be unknown now, but I will become the greatest swordsman in the world!
quotes.speaker: Zoro

quotes.text: I'm not the kind of fool who hunts rabbits with a cannon. This tiny blade is more than enough for the East Blue.
quotes.speaker: Mihawk

quotes.text: A wound on the back is a swordsman's shame!
quotes.speaker: Zoro

quotes.text: It's too soon for you to die. My name is Dracule Mihawk! Discover yourself, grow strong, and return to challenge me again!
quotes.speaker: Mihawk

quotes.text: Luffy... can you hear me? I'm sorry for worrying you. If I fail to become the world's greatest swordsman, you'll be disappointed, right? I will never lose again! Until I defeat him and become the greatest, I will never lose again!
quotes.speaker: Zoro
quotes.context: Making his vow after the defeat

themes.description: The episode explores the gap between ambition and current ability. Zoro's dream of becoming the world's greatest swordsman is confronted with the reality of how far he still has to go.
themes.symbolism: Mihawk represents the peak that Zoro must climb. The small dagger symbolizes how insignificant Zoro currently is compared to the top tier.

themes.description: Zoro's refusal to flee or show his back to an enemy, even in the face of certain death, embodies the samurai code of honor.
themes.symbolism: The scar on Zoro's chest becomes a badge of honor rather than shame, representing his willingness to face defeat rather than run.

themes.description: Despite the vast power gap, Mihawk shows genuine respect for Zoro's courage and determination, choosing to spare him and encourage his growth.
themes.symbolism: Mihawk switching from the small dagger to Yoru represents acknowledging Zoro as a true swordsman worthy of respect.

themes.description: Zoro's promise to Kuina drives him to fight despite impossible odds. His vow to Luffy becomes an equally unbreakable commitment.
themes.symbolism: Wado Ichimonji surviving the duel represents Kuina's spirit protecting Zoro and the unbreakable nature of their promise.

characterSpotlights.role: Protagonist in defining moment of defeat and growth
characterSpotlights.development: Zoro experiences his first true defeat, learns humility, and makes an unbreakable vow. This moment transforms him from a confident swordsman into someone who understands the true path to greatness.
keyActions: Challenges Mihawk despite knowing he'll lose
Fights with all his strength using three-sword style
Accepts defeat face-forward rather than fleeing
Makes his iconic vow to never lose again
quotes: I have a duty to fight you. My name may be unknown now, but I will become the greatest swordsman in the world!
A wound on the back is a swordsman's shame!

characterSpotlights.role: Legendary swordsman and measuring stick for Zoro's dream
characterSpotlights.development: Introduced as the world's strongest swordsman. Shows both his overwhelming power and his honorable character by respecting Zoro's courage.
keyActions: Fights first with a small dagger to show the power gap
Spares Zoro's life and encourages him to grow stronger
quotes: I attacked them merely to pass the time.
I'm not the kind of fool who hunts rabbits with a cannon.
It's too soon for you to die. Discover yourself, grow strong, and return to challenge me again!

characterSpotlights.role: Supportive captain watching his first mate's defining moment
characterSpotlights.development: Shows his trust in Zoro by not interfering with the duel, respecting Zoro's pride as a swordsman. His reaction to Zoro's vow shows the deepening bond between captain and crew.
keyActions: Decides to stay and fight Krieg while sending Zoro after Nami

mangaDifferences.difference: The anime extends several scenes, particularly the flashback sequences with Kuina, to add emotional weight and runtime.
The anime shows more of the Baratie crew's reactions to the duel compared to the manga's more focused perspective.

trivia.fact: This episode aired on May 10, 2000, and is consistently ranked as one of the best episodes in the entire One Piece anime series.
Episode 24 has a 9.2/10 rating on IMDB, making it one of the highest-rated early episodes of One Piece.
Takeshi Aono, the original Japanese voice actor for Mihawk, voiced the character until his death in 2012. Hirohiko Kakegawa took over the role afterward.
The fight was reanimated in 2012 for the 'Episode of East Blue' special with updated animation quality.
Zoro's vow 'I will never lose again' becomes a defining character trait, and he largely keeps this promise throughout the series with very few exceptions.
This episode covers manga chapters 50 (pages 2-19), 51 (pages 2-19), and 52 (pages 1, 4-20).
